title: Barn Corn Crib
listingDescription: This open wood slated structure was used to store dry corn for feed.

images.altText: A small building with open slatted wood sides for storing grain
images.title: Corn Crib
images.caption: Corn crib has open slatted walls for storing grain.

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
Access to see this building is limited due to Covid-19.

Constructed in 1923 this corn crib originally stored corn grown on the farm and fed to the livestock raised by second owner Ellison Smyth.  The Sandburg's stored various farm equipment here and today garden tools are stored inside.
audioDescription: The Corn Crib sits within the main barnyard area. It is up on pillars about a foot off the ground. The open slated sides allow for air flow for the grain that would have been stored inside.

title: Barn Garage
listingDescription: The barn garage houses historic farm equipment as part of the barn complex of building at Connemara Farms.

images.altText: A white garage with several bays and doors houses farm equipment
images.title: Barn Garage
images.caption: The barn garage houses farm equipment, but was also home to occasional square dances.

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
The interior of this building is currently closed due to Covid-19

The Sandburg's stored farm equipment including the farm tractor and jeep in this building.  Occasionally the equipment was removed for evening square dances, including a group known as the Connemara Farm Dancers.

Listen to the audio to hear Sandburg's granddaughter Paula Steichen talk about the square dances held here.

"The garage at the barn was often used for square dances on Saturday nights. When we had a caretaker Frank Mintz for quite a time who was part of a dancing group, a mountain dancing group, and we would have square dances, he would really hold the square dances there, and sometimes members of the family would go down. I know that Frank Mintz’s group for a while wore the shirts that said Chickaming Goat Herd on them."
audioDescription: The barn garage sits on the edge of the gravel farm lane facing the historic garden area. Access to the goat yard is on the left as you face the barn garage. There are exhibits inside to view during open hours.

title: Be a Junior Ranger at the Sandburg Home
listingDescription: Learn about Carl Sandburg, poetry, goats and more when you participate in the site's Junior Ranger program. Junior Rangers simply visit the park store and request a free booklet, or can download a booklet to complete at home.

images.altText: illustrated image of a large field with the Sandburg Home and a Barn
images.title: Be a Sandburg Home Jr Ranger!
images.caption: Be a Sandburg Home Jr Ranger!

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
Visit Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site and become a Junior Ranger!

Visit the weekend pop-up park store and information area behind the Sandburg Home and ask for a free Junior Ranger program or download a digital booklet before you visit. Then, explore the park to complete the activities appropriate for your age, show it to a ranger, and you will earn a badge and the honor of being a Junior Ranger who vows to learn about and protect National Parks throughout our country.

If you cannot visit Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site, simply download a Junior Ranger booklet. For a Spanish language booklet, plelase email the park. You can use the museum web exhibit to find the information needed to complete the activities, then mail or scan and email the booklet to the park for a ranger to check. We will mail the booklet back to you with your badge. In order to be efficient with mail, we only mail badges/completed booklets back to visitors. If you have questions about the program, please contact the park by email.
audioDescription: The Junior Ranger program starts at the Sandburg Home in the ground level visitor information and park store area. When you enter the door under the porch turn to your right and walk towards the information desk to request a booklet.

title: Bean Lake, Missouri

images.altText: Black and white photo of men working on laying down railroad tracks in 1900.
images.title: Bean Lake, Missouri

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
The next stop was the railroad section gang at Bean Lake, Missouri. After doing intense, hard labor for two weeks, because of financial struggles for the railroad and the fact that Sandburg didn't have an address at the time, he wasn't paid for his work.

He writes:

My Irish boss, Fay Connors, hired me at a dollar and twenty-five cents a day and I was to pay him three dollars a week for board and room in his four-room one-story house thirty feet from the railroad tracks. I tamped ties several days from seven till noon, from one till six in the evening. On Sunday I washed my shirt and socks. At the end of two weeks, on a Sunday morning, I hopped a freight for Kansas City and left Boss Connors to collect for my board and room out of my paycheck. The rest of the pay was still owing and was never collected. If Connors did get it he couldn’t have sent it to me, as he didn’t know my address and I wasn’t expecting to have any address for weeks or months.

title: Buck Kid Quarters
listingDescription: This smaller barn is one of several barn structures within the landscape of Connemara Farms and provided extra housing for nursing moms and kid goats, or during weaning periods.

images.altText: A small red barn with an A frame roof and three doors to a stable, a loft, and a side room.
images.title: Buck Kid Quarters
images.caption: Young boy goats (bucks) live here when old enough to leave their mom.

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
Access to see this building is limited due to Covid-19.

Mrs. Sandburg housed her young buck kids in this building and adjacent play yard until they were old enough to join the older bucks or be shipped off to other dairy goat farms. 

Today the park uses this building and play yard in the spring for does and their new kids.  Later in the summer, once the buck kids reach four to six months old they are separated from the herd and housed here until they are large enough to join older bucks across the road or are sold to another farm.
audioDescription: This little red barn is set within the main fenced barnyard area, to the right of the big barn, but provides separate living quarters for goats throughout the year. It has its own fenced play yard area as well.

title: Chicken House
listingDescription: Previously used as lodging for enslaved laborers, the Sandburg family converted this building to house a chicken coop, and play area for young goats.

images.altText: White building with doors and windows with a fence surround
images.title: Chicken House
images.caption: This building served many purposes over time.

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
Constructed in the 1840's the first owner of this property, Christopher Memminger, housed enslaved persons in this building while he lived here in the summers.  Living near the main house they likely helped with domestic tasks of cooking and cleaning, however little is known about these early enslaved workers.

The second owner, Ellison Smyth installed large wash tubs in 1924 and called it the "wash house".

In modern times, Mrs. Sandburg used the left side of the building for chickens and the right side for young goats.

Sandburg's granddaughter, Paula Steichen discusses how the family used the building.

"It was used first for chickens, and then we used it primarily for baby kids that we raised after the kids were old enough to be moved from in the basement of our house, we would take them out there. The kids of course were separated from the does as soon as they were born so they had to be kept in separate quarters."
audioDescription: One of three outbuildings, set next to the large main house at Connemara Farms. This historic white building has two doors, several windows, as well as a ramp and small door into the building for chickens and young goats that would have been inside the fenced yard.

title: Cow, Chicken and Storage sheds
listingDescription: This shed houses the farm chickens.

images.altText: A little red building with windows and a hatch door for chickens
images.title: Cow and Storage Sheds
images.caption: The chicken house in the barnyard area.

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
Access to see this building is limited due to Covid-19.

The Sandburg's kept a family milk cow in this shed and sawdust for the goat barn in the storage shed behind it.

Today the cow shed is used to care for chickens of similar breeds to those Mrs. Sandburg raised. The Sandburg chickens were housed in a building up the road by the main house.  Saw dust for the goat barn is still stored in the shed behind it.
audioDescription: This little red building is accessed through the main barn yard area. Go thru the gate to the right and this Chicken Coop building is right in front of this gate.

title: Crow's Nest
listingDescription: Listen to the Crow's Nest Narration

images.altText: The mountains seen from the room called the Crow's Nest
images.title: View from Crow's Nest

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText: This room was named the "Crow's Nest" by Mrs. Sandburg's brother, Edward Steichen.  He likened the room to the lookout on a naval ship because of the beautiful mountain views the family enjoyed from the large window.  Carl Sandburg considered using this room for a study, but decided the view was too distracting.
audioDescription: This room is on the third floor and over the front porch.

title: Denver, Colorado

images.altText: Black and white photo of two men washing dishes in a bucket on a crude wooden table behind a kitchen
images.title: Denver, Colorado

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
Sandburg took a Colorado Midland train to head back east to Denver. This was the first time Sandburg "rode the bumpers" (the couplers between train cars) late at night. He was so exhausted that he fell asleep while standing on the bumpers and later considered himself very lucky he didn't fall to his death that night.

In Denver, Sandburg found work in the Windsor, a high-class hotel, washing dishes.

He writes:

I saw Pikes Peak so I could say I saw it... I washed dishes for two weeks, collected a dollar and fifty cents a week, a cubbyhole for a room and meals as good as were served to the silk-hat guests. Then came the question whether I should head for the West coast or east to Galesburg. I admitted I was a little homesick for the faces and streets of Galesburg.

After this stint in Denver, Sandburg headed back to his hometown.

title: Dining Room
listingDescription: Listen to Dining Room Narration.

images.altText: Windows, a dining table with four mix matched chairs and a TV sits between two filled bookcases, a
images.title: Dining Room

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
The aromas of freshly baked breads, hearty soups or homemade pies filled the Sandburg dining room. Most meals included fresh garden salads, yogurt, goat's milk, and Mrs. Sandburg's special cheeses. Carl Sandburg's red thermos contained fresh brewed coffee with goat's milk and a spoonful of honey.  

While they were a very busy and independent family with a host of varied interests, they came together whenever possible for lunch and dinner. After dinner, Sandburg would often play his guitar for a family sing-a-long, or read from his current work.  Or they might turn on the radio to hear Jack Benny, Fibber McGee and Molly or the evening news. Birds entertained outside while they sat around the table.
audioDescription: As you step out of the Farm Office, you come into the Dining Room, which is at the back of the house, in between the kitchen and a bedroom.

title: Emporia, Kansas

images.altText: A black and white photo of the office of the Emporia Gazette newspaper company.
images.title: Emporia, Kansas

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
Traveling further west to find work for the Kansas wheat harvest, Sandburg headed to Emporia. The trip between Kansas City and Emporia was eventful. The young hobo hopped a train and snuck onto a car, but he was discovered by a "shack" (term used for a train brakeman) during the trip. After punching Sandburg twice in the face the shack left him to ride the train.

In his autobiography, Sandburg reminisced about an early interest in newspaper reporting:

I walked past the office of the Emporia Gazette but didn’t have the nerve to step in and ask the editor, William Allen White, how he came to write “What’s the Matter with Kansas?” I didn’t agree with it but I liked his style. After a big two-bit meal I went to the city park, where I lay on the grass for a sleep.

title: Farm Office
listingDescription: Listen to Farm Office Narration

images.altText: Room filled with books, filing cabinets, images of goats, award ribbons, and office supplies.
images.title: Farm Office

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
From her office in the middle of the house, Mrs. Sandburg paid the bills, answered correspondence and kept both the house and farm running smoothly.  She took care of the day to day business so that her husband could focus on his writing.

In order to manage the large goat herd, Mrs. Sandburg was often in her office studying goat lineages, calculating bloodlines and making breeding decisions based on science. She was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate from the University of Chicago, and had a keen interest in genetics. She sold milk to local dairies, sold goats to North and South America, and kept an active schedule of showing goats at regional contests.

Click the audio below to learn how Mrs. Sandburg and her daughter Helga first started raising dairy goats.

"While we were in Michigan, one of the children, our youngest Helga, wanted a cow and then Carl was the one who said, you can’t possibly handle a cow, but a goat would be the right one for your size to handle. Goats you can just put in the family car and drive off, she went with me anyway to see about the goats since her father really said no, that a cow was impossible. We had some goats near the house, and I not only went home with one goat, but I said two goats, we’ll certainly need two goats if we’re going to have our family milk supply. Those goats turned out to be way out of the ordinary goats, that’s how we got into having goats".
audioDescription: This room sits at the center of the home, entered from Sandburg's Downstairs Study on one side, and the Family Dining Room on the other.

title: Flat Rock Outcrop
listingDescription: This large, exposed rock was a favorite location for Carl Sandburg to bring a chair and orange crate for an outdoors study. He enjoyed the quiet and peacefulness of this location to edit his work. Exposed rocks like this are located throughout the area and have a long history of use going back to the first peoples to settle the area we know today as Flat Rock.

images.altText: image of large flat exposed rock surface surrounded by forest
images.title: Flat Rock Outcrop
images.caption: Flat Rock Outcrop Behind Sandburg Home

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
This large, exposed rock was a favorite location for Carl Sandburg to bring a chair and orange crate for an outdoors study. He enjoyed the quiet and peacefulness of this location to edit his work. Exposed rocks like this are located throughout the area and have a long history of use going back to the first peoples to settle the area we know today as Flat Rock.

This area’s dynamic and ecologically abundant landscape supplied generations of Native Americans a place to develop extensive cultural traditions related to kinship, religion, trade, art, and diverse use of abundant natural resources. Over millennia, these traditions evolved, adapting to environmental and social changes.Take a moment to pause here and reflect on the legacy of this land! These mountains are clothed in a lush hardwood forest teeming with birds, wildlife and an abundance of native berries, nuts, fruit, and flowers.  

Long ago, native peoples such as Cherokee, Cheraw, and Catawba thrived on this rich abundance.While villages were in outlying areas, these large “flat rocks” near the border of North and South Carolina, were noted as places for traders, pioneers, and settlers to barter goods with the native people. With increased European expansion, the Indian Removal Act of 1838 forced native people to leave their homelands and their ancestral lands were confiscated.

This removal was devastating, and many thousands perished on what is tragically remembered as the Trail of Tears. Today descendants of these early Cherokee people embrace their rich ancestry and culture and call these mountains home again in Cherokee, NC. Learn more about the Trail of Tears.
audioDescription: At this stop is a large exposed granite rock. It covers an area of approximately 50 feet by 50 feet square. The surface is uneven with a slope. At the edges where rock meets the forest are small plant communities of lichen and moss which are soft to the touch.

title: Front Porch
listingDescription: Listen to Front Porch Narration

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
Carl Sandburg stood on the porch of his new home in Flat Rock, NC, and declared, "We didn’t just buy two-hundred and forty-five acres when we bought Connemara, we bought a million acres of sky!  They also found at Connemara a writer’s sanctuary and the perfect farm for dairy goats.

As you tour the house you will note that the Sandburg family lived casually.  Simplicity was the rule as indicated by the functional furnishings.

Sandburg followed this philosophy throughout his life, having written to his soon-to-be wife Lilian in 1908, “All the big people are simple, as simple as the unexplored wilderness. They love the universal things that are free to everybody. Light and air and food and love and some work are enough. In the varying phases of these cheap and common things, the great lives have found their joy.”

Connemara provided them all these things; mountain air, gardens and orchards full of vegetables and fruit, plenty of work, and the love of a family.
audioDescription: A large second floor porch about 20 feet wide and 10 feet deep, with four Doric Greek Columns, two on either side of stairs that curve up from the ground below. The porch has two large 4 foot wide doors that enter the main living areas of the house. The porch looks out over the front pasture and lake with mountains appearing in the distance.

title: Galesburg Illinois

images.altText: A colorized postcard of Galesburg Illinois train station and the Sante Fe Train.
images.title: Galesburg, Illinois

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
Galesburg was Carl Sandburg's hometown - where his hobo journey began and ended.

In Sandburg's autobiography "Always the Young Strangers" he wrote:

The family didn’t like the idea. Papa scowled. Mama kissed me and her eyes had tears after dinner one noon when I walked out of the house with my hands free, no bag or bundle, wearing a black-sateen shirt, coat, vest, and pants, a slouch hat, good shoes and socks, no underwear, in my pockets a small bar of soap, a razor, a comb, a pocket mirror, two handkerchiefs, a piece of string, needles and thread, a Waterbury watch, a knife, a pipe and a sack of tobacco, three dollars and twenty-five cents in cash.

A little west of the Santa Fe station stood a freight train. A conductor came out of the station and waved a yellow flimsy in his hand. As the train started I ran along and jumped into a boxcar. From then on I stood at the open side door, watched the running miles of young corn, reading such station names as Cameron and Stronghurst, names of villages and towns I had heard a thousand times and had never had sight of.

title: Goat Barn
listingDescription: This barn is home to descendants of Mrs. Sandburg's champion dairy goats.

images.altText: Goats graze in green pastures with a big red barn in the background.
images.title: Goat Barn
images.caption: Dairy goats and barn at Connemara Farms.

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
Access to see the goat barn is limited due to Covid-19.

The goat barn sheltered the does (girl goats) at Connemara.  Mrs. Sandburg operated a successfull dairy, selling milk from the farm to dairies in Asheville and Greenville.  Many of the farm's goats won top awards at state and local fairs. Jennifer II, a Toggenburg dairy goat, was internationally recognized as the top producing Toggenburg in the world in 1960. 

Mrs. Sandburg helped establish the American Dairy Goat Association, located in Spindale, NC, and was its Director for over ten years. She was honored with a lifetime directorship. A legend in the dairy goat industry, Mrs. Paula Sandburg was a champion of champions.
audioDescription: A large historic red barn, several related outbuildings, as well as live dairy goats are part of the farm complex of buildings on the 245 acres of Connemara Farms.

title: Goat Sheds

images.altText: Two small wooden sheds sit inside a fence pasture area
images.title: Goat Sheds
images.caption: The adult buck sheds and pasture area.

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText: Mrs. Sandburg used these sheds when goats were ill and needed to be isolated from the main herd.  The shed on the right was also sometimes referred to as the "breeding shed" as goats would be brought here in the fall for breeding.  Today only one shed is in use and it houses the bucks (boy goats).  The bucks are separated from the does once they reach four to six months old to prevent unplanned breeding.
audioDescription: These little houses, and fenced pastured areas, are across from the big red barn, near the vegetable garden.

title: Greenhouse and Garden
listingDescription: The greenhouse and root cellar were an important part of seasonal gardening.

images.altText: A long white low building with a solid rood on one side and a glass roof on the other.
images.title: Greenhouse
images.caption: The greenhouse and root cellar near the vegetable garden.

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
Built in 1873 this building served originally as a root cellar.  The Sandburg's used the greenhouse side to start plants for the flower gardens and occasionally stored bulbs in its cellar.

Adjacent to the greenhouse, the Sandburg's cleared up to an acre for a vegetable garden.  The garden provided much of their own food for the year through canning, drying and preservation.  Still used each year to pant a variety of vegetables, this garden retains a strong association with its past.
audioDescription: This building sits across from the green "Farm Manager's House", up near the garden and orchard between the tree line and the garden area.

title: Hikers' Parking Lot

images.altText: View of entrance to hikers' parking lot with directional sign and driveway.
images.title: Hikers' Parking Lot
images.caption: View of entrance to hikers' parking lot.

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
Free parking is available at either the main visitor parking lot or hikers' parking lot.  Visitors using the hikers' parking lot will enter from the opposite side of the park as the main parking lot. There is a gravel road to use to walk into the park to access hiking trails, the Sandburg Home, goat farm and grounds. Please use the map in the parking lot to orient yourself when you visit, or view a trail map here. If you need accessibility assistance, please call 828-707-8125 when you arrive and visit our accessibility page for more information.

Oversize Vehicles
The Hikers' lot cannot accomodate large vehicles such as buses, RVs or towable trailers. Please use the Main Visitor parking lot if arriving with a larger vehicle.

Additional Parking Options

  • Visitors may park behind the Flat Rock Village Offices located at 110 Village Center Drive, Flat Rock, NC. It is a short walk to the park from this lot.
  • Visitors may use the Flat Rock Playhouse lot directly across the street from the main visitor lot, in the morning until noon, and in the afternoon when there are no performances. There will be signs posted at the playhouse to restrict parking for performances. Please be a courteous neighbor and pay attention to their signs.
* If you park at Flat Rock Playhouse, remember to move your car before noon or risk being blocked in for several hours on matinee days (Wednesday through Sunday).

Accessibility
Due to the nature of the gravel surfaces and terrain, this parking lot is not accessible, nor does it provide an accessible route into the park. Visitors with accessiblity needs should use the main visitor parking lot. Signs are posted there on how to contact a ranger for assistance.

title: House Garage
listingDescription: This pre-civil war kitchen building was converted to a garage by the Sandburg family.

images.altText: White garage building with french doors in the middle and garage doors on each side
images.title: House Garage
images.caption: The house garage was originally the kitchen for the home.

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText: From 1838 until 1945 this was the kitchen for residents of Connemara.  The Sandburg's modernized the main house with an interior kitchen and converted this building into a three-car garage.  Today the interior is used for special events and programs.
audioDescription: White garage building, with French door entrance at the middle and flanked by two garage doors

title: Hutchinson, Kansas

images.altText: Black and white photo of an unkempt woman and two kids, in the background is a rundown house.n house
images.title: Hutchinson, Kansas

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
In Hutchinson, Sandburg learned that people who lived near the tracks were less likely to help out errant travelers because they were approached so often.

In his autobiography, he remembered:

I walked eight or ten blocks and hit two houses. "Have you got any work I can do for breakfast?" They took one look at me and shut the door. At the third house a woman sent her daughter to get me a saw, showed me a woodpile and a sawbuck. For an hour I kept the saw going, piled the wood, and went to the house.The smiling mother and daughter led me to the family table, set fried ham and potatoes, apple sauce, bread and coffee, before me.

title: Janet's Bedroom

images.altText: A room with a twin bed, books, chair, typewriter and card table, with knic knacs and personal items
images.title: Janet's Room

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText: Sandburg's middle daughter Janet helped out with the farm work, getting up every morning at 5:30 am to feed the baby goats.  Later in the day she helped with the housework.  In her room, she read, drew, wrote letters, and compiled scrapbooks.
audioDescription: This room is one of two rooms on the right side of the 3rd floor of the historic home. There are two rooms opposite with the Crow's Nest in the front Center.

title: Kansas City, Missouri

images.altText: A sepia toned postcard showing the Kansas City Train Station in early 1900's
images.title: Kansas City, Missouri

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
After arriving in Kansas City, Sandburg had little trouble finding his next job.

In Kansas City Mrs. Mullin had a sign in the window of her restaurant on Armour Avenue, “Dishwasher Wanted.” ... It was a fight in that dish trough to get enough dirty dishes cleaned for serving the customers. I swept the eating room morning and afternoon and mopped it on Saturday. My sleeping place was the end of a hallway with my cot curtained off, and I washed and shaved, using my pocket mirror, at a sink and faucet in the hall... I worked every weekday till eight o’clock at night except for an hour or two in the afternoon. I had three good meals a day. I had Sunday off and walked miles around Kansas City comparing it to Galesburg, Peoria, Keokuk, and Chicago.

title: Keokuk, Iowa

images.altText: Black and white photo of a steamboat being loaded at a wharf on the river
images.title: Keokuk, Iowa

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
His arrival in Keokuk marked the first time Sandburg had ventured outside the state of Illinois. He later remembered seeing the Mississippi River for the first time as one of the most awe-inspring sites on his whole journey.

Crossing the long bridge over the Mississippi my eyes swept over it with a sharp hunger that the grand old river satisfied.

A captain of a small steamboat offered the young Sandburg passage to Keokuk for work "shouldering kegs of nails to the wharves."

It was in Keokuk that Sandburg met his first fellow hobo. This man was a "tramp," which meant he didn't work for money, but instead relied on the kindness of strangers to survive. He taught Sandburg that a "lump" meant food that was given as a handout, and "sit down" was a phrase used when someone would invite a tramp to the kitchen table to eat.

Sandburg also found work in Keokuk that would provide some extra cash and meals. He spent a day going door-to-door with a can of asphaltum for blackening rusty stoves, and then:

I saw a sign “Waiter Wanted” in a small lunch counter near the end of Main Street. He said I could make myself useful at 50 cents a day and meals.

After a day working at the lunch counter, Sandburg slept that night in a boxcar that took him halfway across Missouri.

title: Lakin, Kansas

images.altText: Two vintage photos, a man on the rails between train cars and a man jumping on a boxcar with a sac.
images.title: Lakin, Kansas

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
In Lakin, Sandburg took advantage of the Kansas wheat harvest by working for another threshing crew for about three weeks.

The work came easier with getting used to it. The dust in your nose and eyes, the chaff sliding down your sweating back, you got used to. One evening at six o'clock the boss said there was only two hours of threshing left and a full moon would be up. We ate supper, at seven went on threshing by the light of a bright full moon, and finished at nine o'clock.

On Sandburg's trip out of Lakin, a "shack" (train brakeman) kicked him off the bumpers of a fast freight. Riding the bumpers refers to standing on the couplers between two cars and keeping hold of the brake rod for stability. It was extremely dangerous.

title: Larned, Kansas

images.altText: Black and white photo of man in overalls using a wheat rake in a field.
images.title: Larned, Kansas

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
Larned was the one place on Carl Sandburg's journey where he refused to refer to himself as a hobo. His father had owned and paid taxes on a quarter section of land in that town.

He wrote in his autobiography:

When I walked past the courthouse I felt like an important, respectable citizen, even though I was sleeping in empty boxcars that stood on the Santa Fe tracks.

Sandburg's work in Larned included assisting a local carpenter for three days at seventy five cents a day and a wheat threshing crew for five days.

title: Lindsborg, Kansas

images.altText: Black and white photo of two men loading hay onto a horse drawn wagon, haystacks stand in the field.
images.title: Linsborg, Kansas

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
After a day in Hutchinson, Sandburg traveled to Lindsborg - a predominantly Swedish community. He worked a hay and broomcorn harvest with several other Swedes on a farm near Lindsborg. Although he was staying among people of the same heritage, Sandburg didn't necessarily get along with them.

I stayed three days at a dollar a day and meals, sleeping in a barn hayloft. On my third and last morning I had been awake a few minutes when I heard voices down below. One voice came clear to me, a Swede saying, "Is that bum up yet?" I said to myself, "Am I a bum?" And I answered, "Yes, I am a bum."... The first time in my life that I heard myself referred to as a bum was among Swedes I had made a detour to see.

title: Main Visitor Parking Lot

images.altText: View of entrance to main visitor parking lot with driveway and parking spaces.
images.title: Main Visitor Parking Lot
images.caption: View of entrance to main visitor parking lot.

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
The pedestrian bridge over the Front Lake dam at the main park entrance is closed. To access park buildings, restrooms, and trails on foot during the closure, visitors must now walk an additional 0.4 mile around Front Lake, and then walk 1/3 mile up a steeply graded hill to the Sandburg Home and farm. Be prepared for this detour when you arrive. View a trail map with the detour here. If you need accessibility assistance, please call 828-707-8125 when you arrive and visit our accessibility page for more information.

Due to the Front Lake bridge closure, a shuttle service is available on Thursdays, Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays from Friday, September 2 – Sunday, October 30, 2022. The free shuttle will transport visitors from the main parking lot, on Little River Road, to the Sandburg Home and goat farm.

Free parking is available at the entrance to the park. The parking lot has three oversize vehicle parking spaces for RV's and buses. Vehicles with trailers will be unable to park in these spaces and should use the playhouse lot across the street subject to availability. On busy days the lot fills quickly.
 

Additional Parking Options

  • There is a Hikers' Parking Lot located 1/2 mile down Little River Rd from the Visitor Parking Lot for visitors who are just coming to enjoy a hike in the park.
  • Visitors may park behind the Flat Rock Village Offices located at 110 Village Center Drive, Flat Rock, NC. It is a short walk to the park from this lot.
  • Visitors may use the Flat Rock Playhouse lot directly across the street in the morning until noon and in the afternoon when there are no performances. There will be signs posted at the playhouse to restrict parking for performances. Please be a courteous neighbor and pay attention to their signs.
* If you park at Flat Rock Playhouse, remember to move your car before noon or risk being blocked in for several hours on matinee days (Wednesday through Sunday).

Accessibility:
There are 2 accessible parking spaces in the main visitor lot. The walk from the visitor parking lot to the home is 1/3 mile and gains 100 feet in elevation. This can be challenging for many visitors. If you feel this climb may be a challenge for you, please call a park ranger from your cell phone using the phone number posted at the accessible parking spaces. The ranger will either be able to provide a shuttle or will make other accommodations.
audioDescription: The main visitor parking lot is an asphalt paved lot with 30 passenger car spaces, 2 accessible spaces and 3 bus parking spaces. All spaces are marked with lines on the asphalt and the accessible spaces have a sign with a blue background and a white line drawing of a wheelchair.

title: Margaret's Bedroom
listingDescription: Listen to Margaret's Room Narration

images.altText: Margaret's room has two twin beds, a TV, sewing machine, and shelves lined with books
images.title: Margaret's Room

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText: Sandburg's oldest daughter Margaret used this room when the family first moved to Connemara.  Later she moved downstairs and the room was used as a guest bedroom. Granddaughter Paula remembers staying here on her visits, and there was a television in the room that Janet watched occasionally.
audioDescription: One of two bedrooms on the right side of the landing in the historic home. There are two bedrooms on opposite side, as well as the Crow's Nest in the middle front.

title: Margaret's Garden and Gazebo
listingDescription: This green lattice building was built next to Margaret's garden and offers a quiet place to sit and observe nature.

images.altText: Green Lattice framed octagonal shaped open garden shed with inside benches
images.title: Garden Gazebo
images.caption: The garden gazebo on the grounds of Connemara.

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText: The Sandburg's oldest daughter Margaret cared for this "wild, overgrown, and beautiful" fenced garden of roses, peonies and perennials.  She used the gazebo to store her garden tools.
audioDescription: This small green lattice octagonal garden gazebo sits next to the chain link fenced garden know as Margaret's garden. It is on the left just as you come up the hill from the lake parking lot. The lane splits off to the left by Margaret's garden and continues up to the main house.

title: McCook, Nebraska

images.altText: Black and white photo of man riding on top of a train with a bedroll.
images.title: McCook, Nebraska

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
Carl Sandburg spent very little time in McCook, but the trip there was interesting. Along the way, police officers were checking boxcars for vagrants so Sandburg decided to hide on top of the car. Hanging on for dear life, he traveled from Denver to McCook. Upon arriving, Sandburg dismounted and was immediately told to leave the city.

I climbed down and started to walk out of the yards. A one-eyed man in plain clothes with a club and a star stood in my way. "Where did you come from?" His tone was horstyle. "I just got off that train," I said. He gave me my orders in a more horstyle tone: "We don't want the likes of you in this town. You get back on that train."

And with that, Sandburg climbed back onto the roof of the boxcar and headed out of McCook.

title: Milkhouse
listingDescription: The Milk House was where goat milk was processed and bottled at Connemara Farms.

images.altText: A gray stone building sits behind a large red barn
images.title: Milkhouse
images.caption: The Milkhouse where goat milk was processed and bottled.

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
The Sandburg's built the milk house in 1948 to process and bottle milk for sale on the farm.  Pipes run from the milking parlor inside the barn into the milk house to be strained and separated before bottling.  Quart-size cardboard bottles were affixed with "Connemara Farms" caps and sold to local dairies and individuals.  

After mandatory pasteurization laws were passed in the early 1950's, Mrs. Sandburg no longer sold milk directly, but collected the milk in large containers to be sold to larger dairies for pasteurization and distribution.
audioDescription: The Milk House is part of the farm complex of buildings. As you walk into the main barn yard area, there is a gate to the right that provides access to see the chickens and coop, and then continue to the back of the barn for access to the gray stone milk house.

title: Mrs. Sandburg's Bedroom
listingDescription: Listen to Mrs. Sandburg's Bedroom Narration

images.altText: A large open room with two twin beds, a chaise lounge, vanity, bookshelves, and a alcove bay window.
images.title: Mrs. Sandburg's Bedroom

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
Lilian Steichen Sandburg was married to Carl Sandburg for 59 years.  Carl called her Paula throughout their marriage.  While living at Connemara Sandburg would now and then go to the bay window in her room and lie on the day couch to listen to a record or take a short nap in the afternoon.  Then he and Paula would often go for a walk on the trails behind the house.  

He fell in love with her from the moment they met, and wrote a poem to her called Paula, a portion of which reads: 

When I saw you, I knew you as you knew me.
We knew we had known far back in the eons
When hills were dust and the sea a mist.
audioDescription: This bedroom is one of three rooms at the front of the house. It sits on the left side with a bay window and a view of front pastures

title: Nebraska City, Nebraska

images.altText: Black and white photo of five men in 1900. The two on each end are seated, all don hat and cane.all
images.title: Nebraska City, Nebraska

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
In Nebraska City, Sandburg spent his time picking apples and chopping wood in exchange for two sitdowns (meals at the kitchen table). He also met a lawyer who hired him on to chop wood.

About the lawyer, he wrote:

Seeing my suit of clothes somewhat ragged, [he] asked me if I would like an old suit of his. He brought it out, an iron-gray all-wool suit, better than any I had had in my life.

title: Omaha, Nebraska

images.altText: Black and white photo of Omaha, Nebraska city in 1890
images.title: Omaha, Nebraska

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
Omaha was the last city on Sandburg's Hobo Journey.

For work in Omaha, he was a dishwasher at the Hotel Mercer for a dollar and fifty cents a week. Unfortunately, for the second time on his journey, Sandburg worked a job without pay.

He writes:

It was a little queer how standard was the wage rate for a dishwasher. It never went as low as a dollar and twenty-five cents a week nor a high as a dollar and seventy-five cents a week... The hotel was leased and run by a fancily dressed tall man who slid and slunk rather than walked around the place. He was known as Wink Taylor... At the end of the first week I didn't get my standard pay of a dollar and fifty cents nor likewise at the end of the second week. Then came the word that the Hotel Mercer was closed, gone, up the spout, foreclosed, and Wink Taylor vanished.

In his writings about Omaha, Carl Sandburg reflected that during his travels he had considered joining the Army multiple times. He remembered walking past the recruiting offices in Kansas City, Denver, and Omaha, but each time he neglected to go inside. Sandburg would eventually go on to join and serve during the Spanish-American War.

title: Park Store and Information
listingDescription: The Visitor Center/Park Store is open Wednesday to Sunday (5 days per week) from 10am to 4pm, inside the Sandburg Home. The online park store is open everyday! The Park Store and visitor information area is a great place to start your visit! You can find information to plan your visit, get a passport stamp, participate in the Jr Ranger or BARK Ranger programs, and get a schedule of upcoming events. The park store has a wide range of Sandburg books, media, and other items.

images.altText: image of a bookshelf with retails items displayed including books and postcards
images.title: Park Store and Information
images.caption: Visit the Park Store and Information area at the Sandburg Home

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
The Visitor Center/Park Store is open Wednesday to Sunday (5 days per week) from 10am to 4pm, inside the Sandburg Home. The online park store is open everyday!

The Park Store and visitor information area is a great place to start your visit! You can find information to plan your visit, get a passport stamp, participate in the Jr Ranger or BARK Ranger programs, and get a schedule of upcoming events. 

The park store is operated by America's National Parks, an official non-profit partner of the National Park Service dedicated to supporting the educational mission of Carl Sandburg Home NHS. The park store has a wide range of books, media, educational games, and other items available for retail sale. These products complement the interpretive themes you experience when visiting the park. The park store is located in the Sandburg Home or you can visit the online park store.
audioDescription: Upon arriving at the parking lot at 1800 Carl Sandburg Lane exit your car and follow the sidewalk path as it leads down to the front lake. At the lake visitors have a view of the Sandburg Home at the top of a hill and a choice of taking a wooded path to the left that will lead them around the lake, or continue on the sidewalk to the right. Following the sidewalk to the right, there is a building with accessible restrooms, a water fountain and water bottle filling station, and wall mounted exhibit panels with text and photos featuring images of the Sandburg family at Connemara, and information about Carl Sandburg's life and his contributions to American literature and poetry. There are four picnic tables behind the building for visitor use. Just past this building is a small white bridge. Proceed across the white wooden bridge with the lake to the left and a spillover dam on the right. Follow the gravel trail straight ahead. This portion of the trail is rocky and moderately sloped. It ascends 100 feet over 1/3 mile to the Sandburg Home at the top. As you walk up the rock trail there are fenced pastures, and tall Hemlock trees lining both sides with a historic rock wall between the trail and a road. This trail continues up the hill and at the top of the hill the trail splits into left and right lanes. Visitor restrooms and access to the barn follow the path to the right. The left fork in the lane delivers you to the Sandburg Home where visitor information and park store services are available on the ground floor of the three story historic white home. The entrance to the Visitor Center is underneath the front porch. Inside you can pick up park brochures and maps, purchase house tour tickets, watch a video, shop in the park store and learn more about the park. The Visitor Center bookstore has books, magnets, hiking sticks, cards, and other memorabilia for purchase. Here you can also learn more about other things to do and places to see at the park. If you arrived at the Hikers lot at 81 Carl Sandburg Lane, follow the signs from to the trail from the parking lot to the gravel road. Park Headquarters and the maintenance compound are on the left. You will use a pedestrian path to walk around a closed vehicle gate and back onto the road. Proceed down this gravel road for approximately 1/3 mile keeping in mind occasional park vehicles may use this road. You may stop to visit the goats at the barn area. To continue to the Sandburg Home and visitor center, continue walking on the gravel road for 100 yards. There is a fork in the road. To the left is an accessible public restroom and water fountain, to the right is a paved road leading to the Sandburg Home. Visitors enter the home underneath the porch. Inside you can find park brochures and maps, sign up and pay for house tours, and watch a short documentary. The park store also has books, magnets, hiking sticks, cards, and other memorabilia for purchase. Here you can learn about other things to do and places to see at the park.

title: Pump House
listingDescription: One of many support structures for live on the farm, this small building pumped water from a spring into the barn and houses.

images.altText: Small white wood building with a door and window sits in a wooded landscape
images.title: Pump House
images.caption: The pump house pumped water to the buildings around the farm

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText: From the 1830s until the 1980's this building provided water for the early residents and even park visitors to Connemara.  A reservoir located near the top of Glassy Mountain provided the water supply.  A pump in this building then sent water to the house, the pond in front of the house and down to the barn.
audioDescription: The pump house is a a small concrete block building with white painted frame, a door and a window. It sits behind the Sandburg Home near the wood shed and the spring house

title: Salida, Colorado

images.altText: Black and white photo of a man on bed of train car with the train going through mountains.
images.title: Salida, Colorado

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
After Lakin, Sandburg left Kansas. He slept in a boxcar as the train headed towards Colorado. When he awoke the next morning he looked up and found himself in the Rocky Mountains.

My eyes caught high rises of tumbling land I had never met before. "Jesus," I said, "those are the Rocky Mountains." I hadn't planned it but there they were, rolling formations of rock and pine lifted away high. "There's the Hand of God." I said.

Sandburg spent two days in Salida where he picked pears and earned a few half-dollars.

title: Sandburg Home
listingDescription: This historic 1838 home is the home Carl Sandburg and his family lived in for 22 years. The home, grounds and Sandburg story are preserved as one of our nations treasures.

images.altText: Historic 3 story white home sits on a hill
images.title: Sandburg Home
images.caption: Home of poet and writer Carl Sandburg

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
Access to the Sandburg Home is currently closed due to Covid-19. 

Sandburg stood on the porch of his new home in Flat Rock, NC, and declared, "We didn’t just buy two-hundred and forty-five acres when we bought Connemara, we bought a million acres of sky!  They also found at Connemara a writer’s sanctuary and the perfect farm for dairy goats.

As you tour the house you will note that the Sandburg family lived casually.  Simplicity was the rule as indicated by the functional furnishings.

Sandburg followed this philosophy throughout his life, having written to his soon-to-be wife Lilian in 1908, “All the big people are simple, as simple as the unexplored wilderness. They love the universal things that are free to everybody. Light and air and food and love and some work are enough. In the varying phases of these cheap and common things, the great lives have found their joy.”

Connemara provided them all these things; mountain air, gardens and orchards full of vegetables and fruit, plenty of work, and the love of a family.

Tours of the home are offered daily from 9:30 am to 4:30 pm.  Step inside the ground floor of the house to learn more and visit the bookstore.
audioDescription: Upon arriving from the Front Lake parking lot, or the Hikers Parking lot, the large white 3 story Greek Revival home sits prominently upon the hill overlooking the front lake and pastures. In typical fashion, there are curved stairs leading up to a large front porch with four Ionic Greek pillars. There is a Porte Cochere, on the right side of the home with a glassed in sun room, and screen porch on the opposite side. The home is flanked by several white outbuilding on the right which have been used in a variety of ways throughout history.

title: Sandburg Home - Janet Sandburg's Bedroom
listingDescription: Sandburg Home Janet Sandburg's Bedroom for tour

images.altText: image of a bedrooms with bed, dresser, desk, books stacked on folding tables
images.title: Sandburg Home Janet Sandburg's Bedroom
images.caption: Sandburg Home Janet Sandburg's Bedroom

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText: Sandburg's middle daughter Janet helped out with the farm work, getting up every morning at 5:30 am to feed the baby goats.  Later in the day she helped with the housework.  In her room, she read, drew, wrote letters, and compiled scrapbooks.
audioDescription: Janet Sandburg's bedroom is a large cheerful room with wood floors and a few rugs scattered over it. 2 tables are in the middle stacked with books, letters, paper and photographs for scrapbooking.

title: Sandburg Home Carl Sandburg's Bedroom
listingDescription: Sandburg Home Carl Sandburg's Bedroom for tour

images.altText: image of a bedroom with bed, dresser, record player and tackboard with images
images.title: Sandburg Home Carl Sandburg's Bedroom
images.caption: Sandburg Home Carl Sandburg's Bedroom

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
Carl wanted his study and bedroom located on the west side of the house because he knew that he would be working throughout the night and sleeping late in the morning and he did not want the rising sun to disturb this routine.

After waking in mid-morning, he exercised, doing calisthenics using Indian clubs seen resting against the chair, listening to classical or folk music on his phonograph player, and reading a little before coming downstairs for the day. Clippings of interesting articles and images from magazines hang pinned to the wall.
audioDescription: Carl Sandburg's bedroom is located on the west side of the house on the top floor, adjacent to his study. It has a full size bed with green cover. A dresser stands in the corner and a a record player sits along one wall under a large tackboard filled with magazine clippings.

title: Sandburg Home Carl Sandburg's Study
listingDescription: Sandburg Home Carl Sandburg's Study for tour

images.altText: image of a study with desks, tables, crates, and paper and books stacked everywhere
images.title: Sandburg Home Carl Sandburg's Study
images.caption: Sandburg Home Carl Sandburg's Study

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
Carl Sandburg did most of his writing in his upstairs workroom, amid a clutter of papers, books, filing crates, and boxes. He pinned notes and newspaper clippings to the walls and shelves. He’d peck away with two fingers at his typewriter, which often was perched on an orange crate.

Sandburg completed several books while at Connemara; his novel Remembrance Rock, a one volume edition of the six-volume Abraham Lincoln Biography, his own autobiography titled Always the Young Strangers, and compiled his Pulitzer Prize-winning Complete Poems.
audioDescription: Sandburg's study is located on the top floor of the home. Two small windows allow light to enter a room cluttered with chairs, satchels, a desk, filing cabinets, crates and a stove. The shelves and surfaces are piled with books, files, and papers.

title: Sandburg Home Correspondence Room
listingDescription: Sandburg Home Correspondence Room for tour

images.altText: image of a home office with walls lined with full bookshelves, desks and a typewriter.
images.title: Sandburg Home Correspondence Room
images.caption: Sandburg Home Correspondence Room

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
This study served as an office where Sandburg worked on correspondence and manuscripts, either with the assistance of a secretary or his daughters Margaret and Helga.  The room was usually piled high with filing boxes and books.  The books lining the shelves were loosely organized according to subjects and projects. 

Sandburg read the many letters sent to him daily; mail from his publisher, fellow poets, school children reading and studying his poetry, U.S. Senators, Supreme Court Justices, and even mail from various Presidents of the United States that he had befriended over the years.

A prominent feature of this room is the table constructed from timbers that supported the roof of the White House during Lincoln’s presidency.  The lumber was salvaged from a renovation project at the White House by carpenter George Severin, He used the wood to construct the table as a gift for Carl Sandburg in honor of his Pulitzer prize-winning biography of Abraham Lincoln.

Click below for an audio clip from Sandburg's address to Congress on the occasion of Abraham Lincoln's 150th birthday in 1959.
audioDescription: The Sandburg Home Correspondence Room is the second room on the tour of the Sandburg Home. This room is filled with four walls of floor to ceiling bookshelves, a large picture window overlooking the front porch, three desks and a typewriter perched on a small table.

multimedia.title: Carl Sandburg Address to Congress excerpt

title: Sandburg Home Dining Room
listingDescription: Sandburg Home Dining Room for tour

images.altText: image of a dining room with a table and chairs and 2 walls lined with bookshelves.
images.title: Sandburg Home Dining Room
images.caption: Sandburg Home Dining Room

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
The aromas of freshly baked breads, hearty soups or homemade pies filled the Sandburg dining room. Most meals included fresh garden salads, yogurt, goat's milk, and Mrs. Sandburg's special cheeses. Carl Sandburg's red thermos contained fresh brewed coffee with goat's milk and a spoonful of honey.  

While they were a very busy and independent family with a host of varied interests, they came together whenever possible for lunch and dinner. After dinner, Sandburg would often play his guitar for a family sing-a-long, or read from his current work.  Or they might turn on the radio to hear Jack Benny, Fibber McGee and Molly or the evening news. Birds entertained outside while they sat around the table.
audioDescription: The Sandburg Home Dining Room is located in the back of the house. One wall has 5 windows overlooking a forested back yard. Two walls are lined with floor to ceiling bookshelves. A desk sits in one corner and a TV in the other with a comfortable brown recliner next to it. In the middle of the room is a large table covered in a white tablecloth with 4 chairs. The table is set with dishes ready for a meal.

title: Sandburg Home Farm Office
listingDescription: Sandburg Home Farm Office for tour

images.altText: image of office with bookshelves, dark metal filing cabinets and photos pinned to the wall
images.title: Sandburg Home Farm Office
images.caption: Sandburg Home Farm Office

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
From her office in the middle of the house, Mrs. Sandburg paid the bills, answered correspondence and kept both the house and farm running smoothly.  She took care of the day to day business so that her husband could focus on his writing.

In order to manage the large goat herd, Mrs. Sandburg was often in her office studying goat lineages, calculating bloodlines and making breeding decisions based on science. She was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate from the University of Chicago, and had a keen interest in genetics. She sold milk to local dairies, sold goats to North and South America, and kept an active schedule of showing goats at regional contests.

Click the audio below to learn how Mrs. Sandburg and her daughter Helga first started raising dairy goats.
audioDescription: The Sandburg Home Farm Office is located in the middle of the house. One wall is lined with bookshelves, while the other is lined with filing cabinets full of dairy goat records and business documents. Several photos are pinned to the wall of the family and prize-winning goats along with ribbons and awards.

multimedia.title: Why Goats? Interview with Mrs. Paula Sandburg

title: Sandburg Home Kitchen
listingDescription: Sandburg Home Kitchen for tour

images.altText: image of kitchen with yellow walls, white cabinets, and bowls, recipe books and appliances laid out
images.title: Sandburg Home Kitchen
images.caption: Sandburg Home Kitchen

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
Using fresh vegetables from the garden and meat from the farm or market, all meals were prepared in this kitchen, with the family rarely having a meal out. 

This room only contained a sink and small counter when the Sandburg's moved in since the original kitchen to the home was in an adjacent building. Mrs. Sandburg had new metal cabinets, a refrigerator and even a dishwasher installed here. The oven came from their home in Michigan.
audioDescription: The Sandburg Home Kitchen is a bright cheerful room with deep yellow painted walls, white metal cabinets and several large windows. A work table is in the middle of the room with recipe book, bowls and a mixer ready to start cooking.

title: Sandburg Home Living Room
listingDescription: The Sandburg Home living room for tour

images.altText: image of the Sandburg family living room with a sofa, chairs and large bookcases.
images.title: Sandburg Home Living Room
images.caption: Sandburg Home Living Room

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
Friends and family were entertained in this room, with Carl playing folk music on his guitar and singing, or sharing stories. His daughter Margaret often joined in on the piano. The walls are adorned with photographs by Edward Steichen, Mrs. Sandburg’s brother, and of course Sandburg’s books. An entire boxcare was filled with the 14,000 books Sandburg brought with him from Michigan.  

Not one to point out his own accomplishments,he stored his Presidential Medal of Freedem, his medal from the King of Sweden and his honorary doctorate degrees in a glass cabinet in the corner.
audioDescription: The Sandburg Home living room is the first room that visitors enter on a tour of the home. It is large and furnished with a sofa and coffee table with books and a checker board stacked on top, several armchairs around the room. A fireplace with a picture of Carl and Lilian Sandburg over the mantle and one corner with floor to celing bookshelves, full of books.

title: Sandburg Home Mrs. Sandburg's Bedroom
listingDescription: Sandburg Home Mrs. Sandburg's Bedroom for tour

images.altText: image of bedroom with twin beds, chairs, bookshelves and a large bay window
images.title: Sandburg Home Mrs. Sandburg's Bedroom
images.caption: Sandburg Home Mrs. Sandburg's Bedroom

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
Lilian Steichen Sandburg was married to Carl Sandburg for 59 years.  Carl called her Paula throughout their marriage.  While living at Connemara Sandburg would now and then go to the bay window in her room and lie on the day couch to listen to a record or take a short nap in the afternoon.  Then he and Paula would often go for a walk on the trails behind the house.  

He fell in love with her from the moment they met, and wrote a poem to her called Paula, a portion of which reads: 

When I saw you, I knew you as you knew me.
We knew we had known far back in the eons
When hills were dust and the sea a mist.

Listen to Carl Sandburg read an excerpt from another love poem below.
audioDescription: Mrs. Sandburg's bedroom is located on the front corner of the house. A large bay window with 4 tall windows creates an alcove on one end where a small table and 2 chairs are placed. The middle of the room is a large open space with a floral rug and 2 comfortable lounge chairs with a record player. Twin beds are placed near the doorway.

multimedia.title: Explanations of Love excerpt by Carl Sandburg

title: Sandburg Home Porch
listingDescription: Sandburg Home Front Porch for Tour

images.altText: view from the Sandburg porch with 2 tall columns and a mountain view
images.title: Sandburg Home Porch
images.caption: Sandburg Home Porch

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
Carl Sandburg and his wife Lilian "Paula", stood on the porch of their new home in Flat Rock, NC, and declared, "We didn’t just buy two-hundred and forty-five acres when we bought Connemara, we bought a million acres of sky!" They also found at Connemara a writer’s sanctuary and the perfect farm for dairy goats.

As you tour the house you will note that the Sandburg family lived casually.  Simplicity was the rule as indicated by the functional furnishings.

Sandburg followed this philosophy throughout his life, having written to his soon-to-be wife Lilian in 1908, “All the big people are simple, as simple as the unexplored wilderness. They love the universal things that are free to everybody. Light and air and food and love and some work are enough. In the varying phases of these cheap and common things, the great lives have found their joy.”

Connemara provided them all these things; mountain air, gardens and orchards full of vegetables and fruit, plenty of work, and the love of a family.
audioDescription: The porch of the Sandburg Home is a wooden structure with gray painted wood slat floor, It spans half of the front of the home including 2 front doors and a large picture window. It is supported by 4 tall columns, and simple white painted rails. The view from the porch of the landscape includes a large pasture, trees and the tops of a mountain range in the distance.

title: Sandburg kitchen
listingDescription: Listen to Kitchen Narration

images.altText: A vintage 1950's Kitchen with pie pantry, stove, two sinks, and "modern" metal cabinets.
images.title: Kitchen

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
Using fresh vegetables from the garden and meat from the farm or market, all meals were prepared in this kitchen, with the family rarely having a meal out. 

This room only contained a sink and small counter when the Sandburg's moved in since the original kitchen to the home was in an adjacent building. Mrs. Sandburg had new metal cabinets, a refrigerator and even a dishwasher installed here. The oven came from their home in Michigan.
audioDescription: The kitchen is just off the Dining Room and is one of the three large rooms at the back of the house.

title: Sandburg's Bedroom
listingDescription: Listen to Carl Sandburg's Bedroom Narration.

images.altText: A bed, side table, dressers, wicker rocker, house slippers, and many books fill Carl's room. ks
images.title: Sandburg's Bedroom

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
Carl wanted his study and bedroom located on the west side of the house because he knew that he would be working throughout the night and sleeping late in the morning and he did not want the rising sun to disturb this routine.

After waking in mid-morning, he exercised, doing calisthenics using Indian clubs seen resting against the chair, listening to classical or folk music on his phonograph player, and reading a little before coming downstairs for the day. Clippings of interesting articles and images from magazines hang pinned to the wall.
audioDescription: This room connects to Sandburg's upstairs study through a little passage. These two rooms are on the left side on the third floor of the historic home.

title: Sandburg's Downstairs Study
listingDescription: Listen to Living Room Narration

images.altText: Room filled with floor to ceiling books, desks stacked with books, and papers, vintage typewriter.
images.title: Front Office

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
This study served as an office where Sandburg worked on correspondence and manuscripts, either with the assistance of a secretary or his daughters Margaret and Helga.  The room was usually piled high with filing boxes and books.  The books lining the shelves were loosely organized according to subjects and projects. 

Sandburg read the many letters sent to him daily; mail from his publisher, fellow poets, school children reading and studying his poetry, U.S. Senators, Supreme Court Justices, and even mail from various Presidents of the United States that he had befriended over the years.

A prominent feature of this room is the table constructed from timbers that supported the roof of the White House during Lincoln’s presidency.  The lumber was salvaged from a renovation project at the White House by carpenter George Severin, He used the wood to construct the table as a gift for Carl Sandburg in honor of his Pulitzer prize-winning biography of Abraham Lincoln.

Click below for an audio clip from Sandburg's address to Congress on the occasion of Abraham Lincoln's 150th birthday in 1959.
audioDescription: This room looks out over the front porch of the historic home, and is flanked on the right by the living room and on the left by a bedroom.

title: Sandburg's Hobo Homecoming

images.altText: A colorized vintage postcard of Galesburg Train Station in early 1900's
images.title: Sandburg's Hobo Homecoming

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText: Sandburg arrived in Galesburg on October 15, I caught one freight train after another till I came in sight of Galesburg the afternoon of October fifteenth. I walked along Berrien Street till I came to the only house in the United States where I could open a door without knocking and walk in for a kiss from the woman of the house. They gave me a sitdown and as they had had only two or three letters from me, they asked me where I had been and I told them the half of it. When I showed my father fifteen dollars and a few nickels, he said the money would come in handy and I should watch it. What had the trip done to me? I couldn’t say. It had changed me. I was easier about looking people in the eye. When questions came I was quicker at answering them or turning them off. I had been a young stranger meeting many odd strangers and I had practiced at having answers... Away deep in my heart now I had hope as never before. Struggles lay ahead, I was sure, but whatever they were I would not be afraid of them.

title: Sandburg's Upstairs Study

images.altText: A small desk in the center, is surrounded by loaded bookshelves, stacks of paper, an old wood stove.
images.title: Upstairs Study

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
Carl Sandburg did most of his writing in his upstairs workroom, amid a clutter of papers, books, filing crates, and boxes. He pinned notes and newspaper clippings to the walls and shelves. He’d peck away with two fingers at his typewriter, which often was perched on an orange crate.

Sandburg completed several books while at Connemara; his novel Remembrance Rock, a one volume edition of the six-volume Abraham Lincoln Biography, his own autobiography titled Always the Young Strangers, and compiled his Pulitzer Prize-winning Complete Poems.
audioDescription: This room is one of two rooms on the left as you enter the third floor of the historic home. There are two rooms on the opposite side with one room in the center over the front porch

title: Spring House
listingDescription: The Spring House was used for storing and curing cheeses at Connemara Farms.

images.altText: A square wooden building with wood shingles and a door sits in a wooded area
images.title: Spring House
images.caption: The Spring House was used for storing and curing cheeses.

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
Cool water from a mountain reservoir flowed through the spring house providing a perfect place for Mrs. Sandburg and her daughter Helga to store and cure cheeses made from goat's milk.

Listen to the audio for a description of the cheeses cured here from Mrs. Sandburg's granddaughter Paula Steichen.

"Then we had a little cheese house on the…if you continue on the Memminger path, where my grandmother and mother did make the most wonderful cheeses of all different sorts and flavored them with anise seeds and with all number of herbs. My mother actually wrote an article called “Making Goat Cheese” for the dairy goat journal I believe it was."
audioDescription: Located along a path behind the main house, the Spring House was one of several outbuildings that supported farm operations. It sits between the House Garage and the Woodshed

title: Swedish House
listingDescription: This outbuilding was originally a home for enslaved people in the antebellum period. It was later used for housing family and guests and finally as book storage for Carl Sandburg's thousands of paperback books when he moved here.

images.altText: This little white "gingerbread" cottage sits among tall trees and other historic buildings
images.title: Swedish House
images.caption: The Swedish House held thousands of Carl Sandburg's magazines, newspapers and books.

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText: This building housed the servants of the first two owners.  Carl Sandburg later named it the "Swedish House" because of the scalloped fascia and used it as an overflow library for magazines and books.
audioDescription: This small white building with scalloped trim around the roof line, sits next to the large house. It features a rock fireplace and chimney, several windows and a small access porch.

title: TRACK Trail
listingDescription: Discover what makes the farm, fields and forests so unique at Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site. Pick up a TRACK Trail brochure as you enter the park from the main visitor parking lot. The brochures help young visitors discover different aspects of the park as they visit the Sandburg residence, the goat farm, rolling pastures, mountainside woods, miles of hiking trails, lakes and gardens.

bodyText:
Enjoy the peaceful setting while discovering what makes the farm, fields and forests so unique at Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site. Pick up a TRACK Trail brochure as you enter the park from the main visitor parking lot. 

The brochures help young visitors discover different aspects of the park as they visit the Sandburg residence, the goat farm, rolling pastures, mountainside woods, miles of hiking trails, two lakes, flower and vegetable gardens, and an apple orchard.

To download and print a brochure before you come or to find more TRACK trails in the area, visit kidsinparks.com.
audioDescription: As you enter the park from the main visitor parking lot, you will walk down a path towards a large lake. Just before you reach the lake on your left is a large sign with four brochure holders. The sign provides information about the TRACK trail and the brochures provide the activities to complete to participate.

title: Tenant House
listingDescription: Built around 1910, this "little white house" was a residence for farm assisstants, chauffers and family guests of the Smyth family.  During Sandburg's time it was occasionally used as a residence for farm employees or as a studio for Helga Sandburg's painting.

images.altText: Small white wooden house has two doors opening onto a front porch, with brick chimney.
images.title: Tenant House
images.caption: Tenant House served as a guest house and later an art studio for Sandburg's daughter.
