bodyText: Built around 1910, this "little white house" was a residence for farm assisstants, chauffers and family guests of the Smyth family.  During Sandburg's time it was occasionally used as a residence for farm employees or as a studio for Helga Sandburg's painting.
audioDescription: This little white wooden structure is next to the public restrooms on the historic gravel lane as you come up from the lake parking lot. The main house sits across the lane thru the trees up on the hill. The lane continues past the Tenant House to the barnyard area about 200 yards around the curve.

title: The Farm Manager's House
listingDescription: This house provided lodging for the farm workers of both the Smythe and Sandburg families. Today, it provides lodging for seasonal park staff and researchers.

images.altText: Green farm home with white trim sits on a farm landscape
images.title: Farm Managers House
images.caption: The Farm Managers house sits near the barnyard area.

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText:
This residence was constructed around 1915 to serve as the home for Smyth's farm caretaker and his family.  The Sandburg's continued this use when they hired Frank Mintz in 1946 to tend Connemara Farms.  He helped by feeding, milking and breeding the goats, plowing the fields and making repairs to buildings.

In the 1960's Leroy Levi moved in with his family to serve as farm manager.  Today the house is used as a residence for temporaray employees and in the spring for the Carl Sandburg Writer-in-Residence.
audioDescription: The big green farmhouse with two small porches and two stories sits on the hillside next to the farm complex on the right side of the gravel lane. The root cellar and gardens sit across the lane on the left.

title: The Horse Barn
listingDescription: The goat barn has a section that was just for the horses on the farm.

bodyText:
Access to see this building is limited due to Covid-19

The grandchildren, Paula and John Carl each had a horse to ride through the pastures and along the many trails throughout the property. This building housed their horses, saddles and tack.  Work horses for plowing were also kept here.
audioDescription: A smaller section of the large red barn is the Horse Barn, which is on the right side of the larger barn area, with a separate entrance door.

title: The Journey Begins: A Hobo Tour Intro

images.altText: A black and white photo of a man sitting in a boxcar, layered on a background photo of train
images.title: The Journey Begins: A Hobo Tour Intro

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText: At the age of 19 Carl Sandburg was a restless young man, anxious to find himself and to see the country. Prior to  his Hobo adventure Sandburg had only traveled as far as  Chicago. He was drawn to head west to Kansas, in time for the wheat harvest, where there would surely be work. Along the way, he would stop to find odd jobs to fund his travels and to keep food in his belly. Sandburg left his friends and family in Galesburg Ill on the last week of June in 1897, he returned to his hometown on October 15th of that same year.  In reference to his hobo travels, Sandburg wrote, I was meeting fellow traveler's and fellow Americans and  what they were doing to my heart and mind, my personality; I could not say then nor later and be certain. I was getting a deeper self-respect than I had in Galesburg, so much I knew. I was getting to be a better storyteller! Quotes used in this tour are Sandburg's own from "Always the Young Stranger". Maps are provided by Library of Congress.

title: Visit Connemara Farms
listingDescription: Outdoor access to the goats (in the barnyard and pasture) is available from 10am to 4pm daily. Visitors to Connemara Farms can see dairy goats that are descended from Mrs. Sandburg's famous herd. She raised three breeds of dairy goats; Saanen, Toggenburg, and Nubian. Each breed can be seen in the herd today.

images.altText: A red barn sits on a hill surrounded by green pastures and grazing goats
images.title: Connemara Farms
images.caption: Connemara Farms barn and dairy goats.

relatedParks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Carl Sandburg Home

bodyText:
Outdoor access to the goats (in the barnyard and pasture) is available from 10am to 4pm daily. 

Visitors to Connemara Farms can see dairy goats that are descended from Mrs. Sandburg's famous herd. She raised three breeds of dairy goats; Saanen, Toggenburg, and Nubian. Each breed can be seen in the herd today.

Mrs. Sandburg owned and operated a goat dairy from 1935 to 1965. Here at Connemara, Mrs. Sandburg's goat breeding program produced champion goats and led to the improvement of goats as milk producing animals.

Rangers and volunteers are on hand to share this fascinating story about goats and Mrs. Sandburg's dairy goat operation. Learn more here.
audioDescription: A large red barn sits prominently on the hillside with a small herd of goats grazing on green pastures.

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
bodyText: In addition to storing wood for the fireplaces, the Sandburg's stored older farm equipment here including a poultry feeder, a baby chick house, cream seperator, plows, mowers and unused building materials.
audioDescription: This building sits up on a rock wall behind the house, along the trail to Glassy Mountain. It is just past the smaller, Spring House, and Pump House. It has three wooden sides, and is open along the trail side. A wire fence protects farm equipment inside.
